DOC.HEAD: Heating Oil Prices Continue to Rise
Eds: CORRECTS closing price on crude to $22.33 in 7th graf
DOC.TEXT: The cold spell that put parts of the country in a deep freeze continued to make heating oil a hot commodity Tuesday, but traders said the frenzied price rally has slowed as many dealers decided to cash in on the recent runup. ``Clearly it ran up just a little too far and a little too fast,'' said John Hill, a vice president for Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. ``Some of the buying we saw was panic buying. ``Yes, it's cold ... and there's some tightness in supply, but we're not running out of heating oil.'' On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the January contract for No. 2 home heating oil rose 0.35 cent to 75.01 cents a gallon, after soaring more than 7 cents in the last two trading sessions. Traders said profit-taking kept the price from rising even higher, and the feeling that the current cold temperatures and inclement weather won't last too much longer helped push down the prices of contracts for February, March and April. Still, the current wholesale price is now at the highest level since the winter of 1985-86, according to Hill. Meanwhile, the January contract for West Texas Intermediate, the leading grade of U.S. crude oil, was up 11 cents to settle at $22.33 per 42-gallon barrel. The contract had jumped $1.12 on Monday to an eight-month high, but traders attributed that sharp increase largely to the fact that the contract was set to expire on Tuesday. January unleaded gasoline lost 0.58 cent to close at 53.93 cents a gallon, after gaining 1.71 cents on Monday. Some traders attributed that drop to internal market influences.
